sub_title: Postdoctoral Researcher Global Commission on the Economics of Water
summary:
I am active in the field of water, making contributions to address a diverse range of water-related challenges. Holding a PhD from the Amsterdam Institute for Social Science Research at the University of Amsterdam, I have over 5.5 years of academic research experience in water governance and international development and possess robust research and analytical skills. My unwavering passion lies in conducting research and shaping policies related to inclusive development, water justice, and water property rights, with a specific focus on the Global South. My research journey has taken me to Malawi, India, and South Africa, where I have collaborated with NGOs, governmental bodies, and esteemed research institutes.

Fuelled by an insatiable curiosity, I remain driven to continuously enhance my knowledge and skills through policy-oriented research. My work ethic is characterized by high motivation, attention to detail, and adaptability, enabling me to excel both independently and as a team player. I am proficient in English and Dutch, coupled with exceptional writing and communication skills, further bolster my qualifications.

awards.title: Honourable mention: Best graduate of 2018
awards.description: Best graduate of 2018 of the Msc Water Management and Governance. Nominated to represent the MSc Water Management and Governance programme for the Koninklijk Nederlands Waternetwerk (KNW) "Waternetwerk Scriptieprijs 2018" (Thesis Award 2018).

awards.title: Cultural Foundation Grant (research grant)
awards.description:
I have been awarded a prestigious Cultuurfondsbeurs (Cultural Foundation Grant) from the Prins Bernhard Cultuurfonds for conducting a 3 month research in South Africa. 

'Cultural Foundation Grants are awarded every year bij the Prince Bernhard Cultural Foundation. All grant recipients are graduate students of university or higher professional education who belong to the top 10% of their generation. There are grants for advanced programmes or research abroad in every academic discipline, the visual and performing arts. The Cultural Foundation Grants enable a wide variety of very talented young people to pursue the careers they dream of.'

projects.title: Water Management for the Andarax Basin - Impact of intensive agriculture on the Tabernas region.
projects.description: A three week research project where we evaluated the current and future (2030) impact of (super) intensive agriculture in the Tabernas region, considering the social, economic, and environmental requirements of the stakeholders present, with a founded explanation as to ‘why’ the current state has emerged (i.e. causal factors, their inter-relation and influence).

contributors.headline: Postdoctoral Researcher Global Commission on the Economics of Water

projects.title: 9 week Field-Research Project in Chikwawa, Malawi
projects.description: A seven-week individual field research project in the district of Chikwawa, Malawi. In this project, which was supported by the NGO Water for People, I looked at different local Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) practices including Community Based Management, Water Point Banking and Permaculture. I assessed these practices by looking at the long-term sustainability, impact on people’s livelihoods, and financial performance. I visit 27 rural villages and conducted over 75 semi-structured interviews. The results of my research have been very useful for Water for People and helped the project move forward and continue successfully. This project was funded by the Scottish Government’s Climate Justice Fund.

projects.title: Carbon Audit at SME
projects.description:
I participated in an innovative collaborative project between the Carbon Trust and the University of Strathclyde, that aimed to provide support to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to reduce their carbon footprint and gives practical experience on environmental responsibilities within a business. 

This project involved carrying out a energy and carbon audit at the SME GalGael. The audit of the company office and the workshop at GalGael took place on the 26/01/15 in the Ibrox area of Glasgow at 15 Fairley St, Govan, Glasgow, G51 2TS.

authors.headline: Postdoctoral Researcher Global Commission on the Economics of Water
Full professor on Environment and Development in the Global South at University of Amsterdam

profile_positions.description:
Post-doctoral researcher supporting the ‘Global Commission on the Economics of Water’. The Commission is an independent body, convened by the Government of the Netherlands and facilitated by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), and chaired by Professor Mariana Mazzucato, WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, Professor Johan Rockström, and Singapore Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. Part of the commission are three leading experts, including Prof. Dr. Joyeeta Gupta. 

The newly launched Global Commission on the Economics of Water will redefine the way we value and govern water for the common good. The new commission will present evidence and pathways for changes in policy, business approaches and global collaboration to support climate and water justice, sustainability, and food-energy-water security.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher | Global Commission on the Economics of Water

profile_positions.description:
PhD candidate within the Amsterdam Institute for Social Science Research (AISSR) in the programme group Governance and Inclusive Development (GID). Doctoral research: Evolving property rights in water and their impact on water allocation and reallocation. (Successfully defended on June 30, 2023). 

Conducted four years of research on property rights in water and their impact on water allocation and reallocation. This involved assessing water laws and policies in 60 African and Asian countries, as well as scrutinising 80 investor-state contracts to land, oil, and minerals. In this period, I contributed to eight publications, attended, and presented at multiple conferences. I was supervised by prof. dr. Joyeeta Gupta (Spinoza Prize winner) and dr. Hebe Verrest.
profile_positions.title: PhD candidate | Evolving Property Rights in Water and Their Impact on Water Governance

profile_positions.description: Alongside my Ph.D., I supported dr. Gupta through contributing to papers, developing budgets, writing project proposals, agenda management, e-mail management, preparing presentations, writing staff advertisements.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: Analysed the status of water 'property rights' in South Africa. Including an in-depth analysis of water law and policy, substantiated by interviews with key stakeholders. Conducted over 50 interviews with key researchers, government officials, and rural communities.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Researcher

company.name: International Environmental Agreements: Politics, Law and Economics (INEA)

profile_positions.company: International Environmental Agreements: Politics, Law and Economics (INEA)
profile_positions.description:
As an editorial assistant I performed a range of administrative and editorial tasks necessary to the production of publications.

International Environmental Agreements: Politics, Law and Economics (IF 2018 = 2.312) is a peer-reviewed, multi-disciplinary journal that focuses on the theoretical, methodological and practical dimensions of cooperative solutions to international environmental problems. The journal explores both formal legal agreements such as multilateral treaties, and less formal cooperative mechanisms such as ministerial declarations and producer-consumer agreements.
profile_positions.title: Editorial Assistant

profile_positions.description:
A three month field-research project in Pretoria/Limpopo/Cape Town, South Africa. Hosted and supported by the Water Research Commission. I assessed the state of water 'ownership' an the implications for water governance in South Africa, conducting an in-dept analysis of the legal framework and related water policy. 

- Conducted over 20 in-dept interviews, from the National Government, to local level. Including top researchers, lawyers, Government officials, NGOs and communal people.
- Analysed the water laws of 19 English speaking African countries.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Researcher

profile_positions.description:
A nine-week field-research project in Blantyre/Chikwawa, Malawi. Hosted and supported by the NGO Water For People. Research in respect to ‘Water Point Banking’, improving the widely practiced Community Based Management (CBM) approach, in order to improve access to water in the rural areas of Malawi.

- Conducted over 40 Interviews. 
- Visited over 35 rural villages in Chikwawa.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Researcher

profile_positions.description:
- Pilot on ‘Lower Impact Denim Finishing’, reduce water footprint in manufacturing.
- Collaborate with WWF on developing a ‘Water Stewardship Strategy’.
- Preparing and implementing ‘Supply Chain Transparency’ pilot.
